title: What kind of colleges would accept a 3.92 unweighted GPA? I have taken 3 AP classes and 1 honors. - Quora
tags: Grade Point Average and University Admissions

response.answer_text: I hope this helps. First off congratulations on your hard work (and some great stats). If you continue in college you’ll probably get into a top 20 grad program too. You didn’t mention it here but your SAT will also be a major factor followed by some great extracurricular activities and leadership. The good news is that you will probably get admitted into several top schools ranked 10–50 especially if you have a commensurate SAT/ACT. The ivys and Stanford will focus more on your intangibles which wasn’t mentioned including leadership, charity, unique and especially national level accomplishments they are rare and unique. Most don’t know this secret (don’t tell anyone) but you’ll definitely want to include several amazing UC schools when applying since these schools feast on kids with your gpa as gpa first schools. With a 3.92 unweighted gpa, top UC campuses including UC Davis, Irvine, Santa Barbara and San Diego will usually accept you with a 1500 SAT or close (UCLA actively recruits straight A students and reject almost anyone not at 4.0/4.0 unless your a special admit The UC are always grade first schools by charter where they have to admit top 8% of California students and the philosophy travels to out of state for grades being significant and most people don’t know that. With those grades, please do apply to some of the best top 50 schools anywhere. phenom schools like Duke, NYU, Notre Dame, Georgetown, Northwestern, Vandy Wash st lousy (I mean louey-it ain’t lousy I visited it and loved it) will carefully consider you especially with a 1500–1550 Sat. Usc admits 11% but would be a great choice if you have some Great activities and leadership. It’s tough to get into USC but if your all around are as good as your grades you’ll get a great look too and possible a scholarship which about 8% do and many are very generous. Also to help determine if you in the intial sweet spot or running, be sure to focus in on the 25th percentile for gpa and sat score at each school you are interested in… if your a special admits —like a first time in family college student or not English speaking at home and on the 75th percentile demarcation if not as per admission experts to stand a reasonable chance. Do some homework and it gives you an idea and definitely not a guarantee of admittance. For the Ivys and hotspots like Stanford, MIT and CalTech, you’ll typically also need a perfect SAT or maybe 1560. It will also help to get into this group if you have a national title nationally renowned extracurriculars and then you’ll have 4–8% chance. These are the toughest schools to get because they focus on quality students gpa but also want “off the chart” SAT scores and world class activities and volunteering. State titles frequently are great for others but might not be your “spike” as some refer to the idea of being special. Good luck on a great academic career thus far and the best news of all is…scholarship possibilities. Also some kids do get rejected from many of the top 40 so be sure to apply to some amazing schools ranked 40-100, some other schools that you truly admire and with a top SAT score, I believe that you’ll get many scholarship offers as well due to a great careers. Keep up the hard work. And lots of continued success.

There are thousands of excellent schools for which you would be competitive. Choose schools based on size, location, and special programs. These need not be “international brand” schools. You will get an excellent education almost wherever you go. I just met a colleague who is now a professor at Cornell University. She started at Agnes Scott College, a very small, all female liberal arts college. She did her Ph.D. at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and now is at Cornell—one of the finest research institutions in the world. Her example is extremely common. If you pick a school where you will be happy and challenged, you will succeed.
